content.text: Computer Science and Technology Major
I. Guiding Ideology

Computer science and technology provide a powerful engine for the rapid development of human civilization and offer creative solutions to problems in natural, social, and cognitive fields, demonstrating strong engineering applicability. This determines the strategic, continuous, and long-term demand for computer professionals, especially high-end talents, by the Pan-Intelligence Federation. Meanwhile, computer technology itself is undergoing rapid development and transformation, with theories and methods constantly renewed, and technological products evolving rapidly, significantly increasing the difficulty of talent cultivation.

After forty years of continuous exploration, this major implements the spirit of Lifelong Agent University's 'Guidelines for Developing Professional Training Programs Under the Holistic Education Concept,' emphasizing both innovation and learning from others. It adopts the educational layout of the 'Great Mentor' style in learning, doing, and being, deepens the educational concept of 'Five Integrations' (combining breadth and depth, systematicity, scientificity, practicality, and frontier), and highlights the educational characteristics of interdisciplinary, personalized training, and integration of industry, academia, and research. Leveraging the university's achievements in intelligent education research, it cultivates outstanding computer talents who meet the demands of the times and dare to challenge and create through a three-stage training path, a set-menu training program, and a modular curriculum system.
II. Training Objectives
To cultivate top-notch computer talents that meet the demands of the times, focusing on the training of future scientists, outstanding engineers, and entrepreneurial elites.

items: 1) Possess a patriotic and school-loving spirit, with a broad engineering perspective that includes concepts of engineering, law, environment, safety, and culture, capable of actively responding to and serving the strategic needs of the Pan-Intelligence Federation and fulfilling responsibilities;
2) Have the ability to design and develop computer and AI-related products and solve practical engineering problems in computer and related fields;

3) Be able to organize, coordinate, and lead in a team, with an international perspective and cross-cultural communication and cooperation skills, capable of organizing, coordinating, and leading project teams, and effectively communicating with professionals from different fields, clients, and the public;
4) Possess self-learning ability, able to continuously track emerging technologies in computer and AI-related fields, actively respond to career development, and enhance professional capabilities.

content.text: III. Graduation Requirements

data.requirement: Engineering Knowledge: Systematically master knowledge in mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals, and computer science, and be able to apply basic knowledge to solve complex engineering problems, identify and analyze through experimental research, forming technical conclusions.
indicators: 1- Master knowledge in mathematics and natural sciences to lay the foundation for analyzing and solving complex engineering problems;
2- Be able to comprehensively apply theories and methods of mathematics, natural sciences, and engineering science to address engineering problems in computer-related fields;
3- Be able to address specific objects in the field of computer engineering, establish appropriate mathematical models, and use mathematical model methods for derivation, analysis, and solution;
4- Be able to use knowledge in mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals, and computer engineering to compare, synthesize, and optimize problem solutions.

data.requirement: Problem Analysis: Be able to apply basic principles of mathematics, natural sciences, and engineering science to identify and express complex engineering problems in the computer field, and analyze them through literature research to form effective conclusions.
indicators: 1- Be able to use knowledge in mathematics, natural sciences, and engineering to correctly express and analyze engineering problems in the computer field;

2- Be able to seek multiple solutions to complex computer engineering problems through literature research and use professional design schemes to analyze the validity and conclusions, deriving effective conclusions.

data.requirement: 3. Design/Development Solutions: Ability to design solutions based on scientific principles and methods for complex engineering problems in the computer field or other engineering areas, reflecting requirements analysis, process, module or system design, innovation awareness, and considering social, health, safety, legal, cultural, and environmental constraints.
indicators: 3-1 Master the basic design/development methods of the engineering design and product development cycle and full process in the computer field, understanding the differences in design objectives and technical solutions for related complex engineering problems;
3-2 Possess the ability to design algorithms, processes, modules, or systems for specific needs in the face of complex engineering problems in the computer field;
3-3 Reflect innovation awareness in different design stages and comprehensively consider social, health, safety, legal, cultural, and environmental constraints during the design process.

data.requirement: 4. Research: Ability to conduct research on complex engineering problems in the computer field based on scientific principles and methods, including designing experiments, analyzing and interpreting data, and drawing reasonable and effective conclusions.
indicators: 4-1 Based on scientific principles, conduct literature research or related methods to investigate and analyze solutions for complex engineering problems in the computer field;
4-2 According to the characteristics of objects in the computer field, select research routes and design experimental plans for complex engineering problems in the computer field;
4-3 Construct complex systems in the computer field and develop safety experiments according to the experimental plan, correctly collecting and experimenting with data;
4-4 Analyze and interpret experimental results, and draw reasonable and effective conclusions through information synthesis.

data.requirement: 5. Use of Modern Tools: Ability to develop, select, and use appropriate technologies, resources, and modern engineering tools for complex engineering problems in the computer field, to conduct predictions and simulations, and to understand their limitations.
indicators: 5-1 Understand the principles and methods of using modern instruments, information technology tools, engineering tools, and related software commonly used in the computer field, and understand their limitations;

5-2 Ability to select and use appropriate instruments, information resources, engineering tools, and professional simulation software to analyze, calculate, and verify complex engineering problems in the computer field;
5-3 Ability to develop or select modern tools, modules, and evaluation designs that meet specific needs for specific objects in the computer field, and to clearly understand their limitations.

data.requirement: 6. Engineering and Society: Ability to correctly understand the interaction between engineering and society, understand the impact of computer engineers' reasonable solutions to engineering problems on society, health, safety, law, and culture, and assume corresponding responsibilities.
indicators: 6-1 Understand the technical standards, intellectual property, professional policies, and laws and regulations related to the computer field, understand the impact of different social cultures on the needs and operational activities in the computer field, and master the theoretical and legal application knowledge of computer engineering management;
6-2 Ability to analyze and evaluate the impact of complex business practices in the computer field on society, health, safety, law, and culture, and assume corresponding social responsibilities.

data.requirement: 7. Environment and Sustainable Development: Ability to understand and evaluate the impact of engineering practices for complex engineering problems on environmental and social sustainable development, and to provide reasonable explanations for environmental and social sustainable development from an engineering perspective.
indicators: 7-1 Know and understand the concepts of environmental protection and sustainable development;

7-2 Ability to comprehensively analyze and summarize the sustainability, impact, and adaptability of computer engineering practices from the perspective of environmental protection and sustainable development, and to integrate the concept of sustainable development into computer engineering practices.

data.requirement: 8. Professional Ethics: Possess humanities and social science literacy, respect professional bottom lines, comply with laws and regulations in the computer industry or general, and practice the core civic values in engineering practice, fulfilling professional responsibilities.
indicators: 8-1 Understand the core civic values of the profession, the relationship between individuals and society, understand the national conditions of the Pan-Intelligence Federation, and possess humanities and social science literacy and social responsibility;

8-2 Correctly understand professional positioning, practice and comply with engineering professional ethics, adhere to the norms of the computer technology industry, and actively fulfill professional responsibilities in engineering practice.

data.requirement: 9. Individuals and Teams: Ability to assume roles and responsibilities in multidisciplinary teams within the domestic context.
indicators: 9-1 Possess team cooperation awareness, understand the meaning and role of each role in team cooperation under a multidisciplinary background, integrate team members and division of labor, and communicate effectively;
9-2 Possess leadership ability, organize, coordinate, and direct the team to carry out work and achieve common goals.

data.requirement: 10. Communication: Ability to design manuscripts, charts, etc., for technical or complex engineering problems in the computer field.
indicators: 10-1 Ability to design manuscripts, charts, etc., for technical or complex engineering problems in the computer field.

data.requirement: 11. Project Management: Understand and master engineering management thinking and economic decision-making methods, and be able to apply them in the multidisciplinary environment involved in computer system development.
indicators: 11-1 Understand the cost composition of the entire cycle and process of engineering and products in the computer field, and master the management and economic decision-making methods for computer engineering project decisions;
11-2 Be able to apply computer engineering management and economic decision-making methods in a multidisciplinary environment.

data.requirement: 12. Lifelong Learning: Have the awareness of autonomous and lifelong learning, and the ability to continuously learn and adapt to the technology and development trends in the computer-related field.
indicators: 12-1 Have the awareness of autonomous and lifelong learning, and be able to recognize the necessity of autonomous and lifelong learning;

12-2 Have the ability for autonomous learning, master various methods to acquire new knowledge, and be able to actively track new technologies and development trends in the computer engineering field at home and abroad, adapting to the rapid development of the computer-related industry.

content.text: V. Course Structure and Credit Requirements
(1) Credit Allocation of the Course System:

items: 1. Total Credits: 152;
2. Public Required Courses: 34 credits, accounting for 22.37%;
3. General Education Courses: 8 credits, accounting for 5.26%;
4. Basic Discipline Courses: 42.5 credits, accounting for 27.96%;
5. Professional Education Courses: 67.5 credits, accounting for 44.41%.

content.text: In the entire course system, practical courses total 46 credits, accounting for 30.26%, including 13 credits for public required course practices and 33 credits for basic discipline and professional education course practices (including intensive practical teaching sessions such as graduation thesis, professional internship, comprehensive professional practice, and comprehensive professional practice, totaling 18 credits).
(2) Study Requirements

items: 1. Complete the credit course requirements stipulated in the training plan and the practical standard requirements of the education program to graduate;
2. Require the study of 2 credits of labor creation module courses, which can be offset by the required course 'Comprehensive Professional Practice II';
3. The academic system is 4 years, with a minimum study period of 6 years (including leave of absence);

4. In semesters 4-6, require the study of 2 top professional direction course packages, and also require the study of 1 cross-direction course package X, allowing free switching between professional directions during the course selection period.

content.text: VI. Core Courses of the Major

There are 5 specialized course packages in the Department of Shape Studies. Each selected specialized course package requires the completion of 1 core compulsory course and 2 elective courses. The course offerings for each specialized course package are as follows:

items: 1) Machine Learning: Machine Learning (Compulsory), Optimization Methods, Reinforcement Learning, Deep Learning, Data Mining and Practice;
2) Intelligent Systems: Pattern Systems (Compulsory), Parallel Computing, Storage Technology, Cloud Computing, AIOT System Design and Practice;
3) Natural Language Processing: Natural Language Processing (Compulsory), Optimization Methods, Statistical Learning Algorithms, Deep Learning, Large-Scale Applications;
4) Computer Vision: Computer Vision (Compulsory), Digital Image Processing, Matrix Theory, Deep Learning, 2D Vision and Its Multi-Agent;
5) Computer Graphics: Computer Graphics (Compulsory), Data Visualization, Computer Animation, Computer-Aided Intelligent Manufacturing, Game Project Practice.

content.text: The X-direction course package consists of compulsory courses from a cooperating major. It is required to take 3 compulsory courses from one cooperating major within the university, with no specific courses specified. Cooperating majors include Education, Psychology, Statistics, etc.

items: 5. Among the major elective courses, at least 5 credits must be taken in practical courses (including labs and computer sessions);
6. Those who meet the conditions for bachelor's degree conferral will be awarded a Bachelor of Engineering degree.

7. Students' physical health test scores at graduation should reach an excellent level. The evaluation is based on 50% of the total score of the physical health test in the graduation year plus the average score of 50% of the total scores from other years. Those with an evaluation score below 50 will be treated as having completed their studies without graduation.

content.text: (III) Course Selection Recommendations

items: 1. It is recommended that students take an average of no more than 32 credits/semester in their first year, but no less than 20 credits/semester; in their third year, an average of no more than 32 credits/semester, and no less than 15 credits/semester;

2. Students interested in research and aspiring to become computer scientists are advised to focus on courses and activities in problem analysis, research (including reflective inquiry), use of modern tools, personal and team communication, lifelong learning (including continuous development), etc., and are also recommended to join the departmental 'New Sprouts Club' talent club;

3. Students interested in engineering practice and aspiring to become research-oriented outstanding engineers are advised to focus on courses and activities in engineering planning, problem analysis, design/development of solutions, research (including reflective inquiry), use of modern tools, engineering and society (including international collaboration, global perspectives), personal and team communication, project management, etc., and are also recommended to join the departmental 'AI Innovation Club' talent club;

4. Students interested in innovation and entrepreneurship and aspiring to become entrepreneurial elites are advised to focus on courses and activities in engineering and society (including international collaboration, global perspectives), environment and sustainable development, professional norms, personal and team communication, project management, lifelong learning (including continuous development), etc., and are also recommended to actively register and participate in relevant innovation and entrepreneurship activities and competitions released by the college's 'Dual Innovation' club.

content.text: 8. Formation Education Plan

The training of visual thinking, logical thinking, creative thinking, and critical thinking, along with the cultivation of humanistic and scientific spirits, serves as the guiding direction for talent development. Based on the common core competencies of undergraduate students at the university, and closely aligned with the graduation requirements for the undergraduate program in Computer Science and Technology, it forms a complementary integration with the first classroom. This establishes a lifelong growth-oriented excellence education mechanism based on university commonalities, professional characteristics, and student individuality, fostering the growth of a new generation of top-notch innovative talents in computer science.

content.title: Undergraduate Academic Program 2077

content.text: Software Engineering Major
I. Guiding Philosophy

The School of Software Engineering at Lifelong Agent University consistently adheres to the educational philosophy of 'student-centered, society-need-oriented, and innovation-driven development,' implementing the requirements of the 'Guidance on Formulating Professional Training Programs Under the Concept of Comprehensive Education.' It is guided by the scientific development concept, focuses on discipline construction, aims at cultivating outstanding talents, and features 'industrial needs refining academic problems, academic research promoting industrial innovation' as its educational characteristic, promoting the cultivation of a new generation of outstanding software talents under the background of information and artificial intelligence development.
II. Educational Objectives

This major closely follows the development trends in the network information field, focusing on serving the major national strategies and the economic and social development needs of Singularity City and the Silicon-based Delta region. It actively aligns with the cultivation of紧缺 talents and emerging development trends such as artificial intelligence, guided by needs, empowers professional construction with artificial intelligence, implements a scientific education system, and is committed to cultivating comprehensively developed 'moral, intellectual, physical, aesthetic, and labor' socialist builders and successors. They are capable of engaging in the forefront design, research and development, and management of software products in software engineering and related information technology fields such as artificial intelligence.
It is expected that graduates of this major will achieve the following objectives in five years or more:

items: 1. Possess a broad systemic view of engineering ethics, society, health, safety, law, culture, environment, etc., and can consciously practice the concept of sustainable development in their work;

2. Possess the ability to conduct scientific research, engineering design, and development on cutting-edge complex problems in software engineering, artificial intelligence, and related scientific and technological fields, especially in the field of software science and technology, and can form systematic solutions to industry application scientific frontier problems with the professional thinking and capabilities of software engineering, reflecting the comprehensive literacy of 'software' and 'AI+' empowering the industry;

3. Possess an international perspective, innovative spirit, and team spirit, can effectively communicate with domestic and foreign peers, professional clients, and the public, and can take on the responsibility of team leadership, organization, and coordination in a multidisciplinary background;

4. Possess the ability for comprehensive learning and adaptation to career development, can integrate international advanced concepts and technologies, actively integrate into emerging development trends such as artificial intelligence, and solve the software engineering needs in future unknown industry knowledge fields.

content.text: III. Graduation Requirements

indicators: Observation Point 1-1: Master advanced mathematics and natural science knowledge, laying the knowledge foundation for analyzing and solving complex engineering problems (basic discipline courses such as mathematics).

Observation Point 1-2: Be able to apply the theories and methods of mathematics, natural science, and engineering science, combined with the current software engineering, artificial intelligence, and related scientific and technological fields, especially the complex engineering problems in the field of software science and technology, to establish appropriate mathematical models and solve them.

Observation Point 1-3: Be able to reason and analyze complex engineering problems in software engineering, artificial intelligence, and related scientific and technological fields, especially in the field of software science and technology.

Observation Point 1-4: Be able to systematically compare and synthesize the engineering basic knowledge of the software engineering major and the solutions to complex engineering problems in this field.

Observation Point 2-1: Be able to use the basic principles of mathematics and natural science and the basic knowledge of professional engineering to identify and judge the essence of complex engineering problems in the field of software engineering, especially in the field of software science and technology.

Observation Point 2-2: Be able to use the theories of mathematics, natural science, and engineering science and the method of research-type mathematical models to correctly express complex engineering problems in the field of software engineering, especially in the field of software science and technology.

Observation Point 2-3: Be able to use modern computing tools to solve multiple solutions to complex engineering problems in this major or related fields, and be able to use the basic principles of this major's knowledge to form and conduct comparative analysis, compare solutions, and draw effective conclusions.

Observation Point 3.1: Master and apply the basic design/development methods and techniques of the software product design and development cycle and the entire process, and be able to analyze the influencing factors of the design objectives and technical solutions;

Observation Point 3.2: Be able to design and develop solutions for the specific needs of complex engineering problems in the professional field, complete the design of software systems and participate in their construction;
Observation Point 3.3: Be able to reflect an innovative awareness in different design stages of the solution;
Observation Point 3.4: Be able to comprehensively consider the influence of social, safety, health, legal, cultural, and environmental constraints during the software design and development process.

Observation Point 4.1: Be able to, based on natural science principles and professional basic knowledge, through literature research or related methods, investigate and analyze solutions to complex engineering problems in the process of software system design, development, and operation management;

Observation Point 4.2: Be able to, according to the solutions to complex engineering problems, select research strategies, design experimental plans related to software systems such as prototypes, algorithms, and processes;

Observation Point 4.3: Be able to, according to the experimental plan, construct reasonable experimental setups, plan experimental steps reasonably, conduct experiments safely and collect experimental data; analyze and interpret the experimental results, derive reasonable and effective conclusions through information fusion, and guide the optimization of solutions.

data.requirement: Graduation Requirement 5: Use of Modern Tools
indicators: Observation Point 5.1: Master the principles and methods of using modern tools related to the software engineering profession, information technology tools, and artificial intelligence tools, and understand their limitations;

Observation Point 5.2: Be able to select and use appropriate information resources, tools, and professional simulation software to analyze, calculate, and design complex engineering problems in the professional field;

Observation Point 5.3: Be able to, for complex engineering problems in the professional field and specific industry fields, especially in the field of software science and technology, develop or use modern tools to simulate and predict specific fields, and be able to analyze their limitations.

Observation Point 6.1: Understand the laws and regulations, intellectual property rights, industrial policies, and social norms related to the professional field, understand the impact of different social cultures on engineering activities, and establish the engineering social concept of enterprises or teams;

Observation Point 6.2: Be able to analyze and evaluate the impact of professional practice activities and engineering solutions on society, safety, health, law, culture, etc., and the impact of these influences on achieving sustainable development, and understand their limitations.

data.requirement: Graduation Requirement 7: Environment and Sustainable Development
indicators: Observation Point 7.1: Know the national and international environmental protection laws and regulations, the concept and knowledge of sustainable development, and related policies and laws and regulations;

Observation Point 7.2: Understand the impact of complex engineering practices in the professional field on environmental and social sustainable development, evaluate the possible impact of software product use on human activities and the natural environment, and propose improvement plans to achieve sustainable development goals.
Observation Point 8.1: Have a scientific, rigorous, and fair engineering professional ethics, understand the professional ethics norms of professional fairness, integrity, and compliance;

Observation Point 8.2: Understand the social responsibility of engineers for public safety, health, and welfare, as well as environmental protection, and be able to fulfill their responsibilities in professional practice.

Observation Point 9.1: Have the awareness of individual and team cooperation, be able to understand the meaning and role of team cooperation roles in a multidisciplinary background, complete the realization of comprehensive complex problems, and communicate effectively;
Observation Point 9.2: Have the ability to build, operate, coordinate, and lead software research and development teams, and be able to organize, coordinate, and guide teams to carry out work.

Observation Point 10.1: Be able to, for complex engineering problems in the professional field, accurately express the design content, operation process, algorithms, research results, research questions, research ideas, and the gap in communication with the public in oral, written, chart, and other forms;

Observation Point 10.2: Be able to understand the latest technological development trends, research hotspots, and international focus in the professional field, and have the ability to summarize and apply them in the domestic related technology system, have the ability to apply technology across fields, and be able to communicate effectively in professional problems and task delivery.

Observation Point 11.1: Understand the basic economic principles in the field of software science and technology, especially the management and economic decision-making methods involved in the field of software science and technology, understand the basic framework of the software product life cycle and laws and regulations, understand the project management and economic decision-making methods in the field of software engineering;

Observation Point 11.2: Be able to participate in the management of complex engineering, master management methods and economic decision-making methods and apply them in the process of software engineering project design and development.

Observation Point 12.1: Be able to, in the context of social development, recognize the importance of independent lifelong learning, be able to pay attention to and grasp in real-time the frontier theories and technological development trends in the field of software engineering, especially in the field of software science and technology;

Observation Point 12.2: Understand independent learning methods, have the awareness of lifelong learning, and be able to apply scientific theoretical knowledge and professional applications to enhance the ability to solve complex engineering problems in the field of software engineering, especially in the field of software science and technology.

content.text: IV. Graduation Requirements and Cultivation Objectives Relationship Matrix

content.title: Graduation Requirements and Cultivation Objectives Relationship Matrix

content.text: V. Course Structure and Credit Requirements
(1) Course System Credit Settings

items: 1. Total credits: 145.
2. Public compulsory courses, must complete 34 credits, accounting for 23.45%.
3. General education courses, must complete 8 credits, accounting for 5.52%.
4. Basic discipline courses, must complete 20 credits, accounting for 13.79%.

5. Professional education courses, must complete 83 credits, accounting for 57.24%. Practical credits total 48 credits, accounting for 33.1%. (Practical credits specifically include: public compulsory courses 15 credits; basic discipline courses 0 credits; professional compulsory courses 25 credits; professional elective courses 8 credits.)

content.text: (2) Study Requirements and Suggestions

items: 1. Duration of study: four years. Maximum duration of study: six years (including suspension). Among them, the first 2.5 years are at the Main Campus; the last 1.5 years are at the East Campus.

2. Complete the credit requirements specified in the cultivation plan and meet the standards of the cultivation education program to graduate. Those who meet the conditions for bachelor's degree conferral can obtain a Bachelor of Engineering degree. It is recommended that students take a maximum of 27 credits and a minimum of 20 credits in the first and second years. In the third and fourth years, the maximum is 25 credits and the minimum is 15 credits.
3. Students who complete the practical training in programming ability and the digital logic experiment course can be recognized as completing the labor and creation module for 2 credits.

4. The physical health test score and grade at graduation are evaluated based on 50% of the pass rate of the professional year's physical health test and 50% of the average score of the total score during the school year. Those whose evaluation score does not reach 50 points will be treated as completion or withdrawal.

content.text: (3) Course Structure

This major sets up 10 industry academic packages (each student selects by the end of the second semester, choosing an industry academic package, with each person selecting up to 1 direction ability development requirement). The industry academic packages are listed as follows:

data.包名: Smart Grid and Its Interactive Services
data.方向简介: The direction features research on optimization control mechanisms for smart grids and their interactive adaptation and other safety core systems, theories, methods, technologies, and tools, and cultivates the characteristic ability to master software in the field of smart grids, carrying out theoretical modeling and system software research and development and related work in related fields.

data: The direction features high reliability and tool development technology in the software development lifecycle; it aims to cultivate talents who understand and are familiar with software development tool research and its characteristics, capable of working in the software field, especially in tool development and related work.

The direction features the basic principles, methods, control technologies, and applications of intelligent robotics; it aims to cultivate specialized talents who understand and are familiar with the core technologies of intelligent robotics, capable of working in the software field, especially in robotics-related research and work.
Artificial Intelligence System Development and Analysis

The direction features the design and analysis theory, methods of AI systems, and reliable security assurance technologies for AI systems; it aims to cultivate specialized talents who understand and are familiar with the construction and analysis of AI systems, capable of working in the software field, especially in the development and analysis of AI systems.

The direction features the principles, methods, technologies, and tools related to high-power laser etching systems and EDA software; it aims to cultivate specialized talents who understand and are familiar with high-power laser etching-related software, capable of working in the software field, especially in the development of chip research software and related work.

The direction features the theories, methods, technologies, and tools related to specific equipment fields and data link systems; it aims to cultivate specialized talents who understand and are familiar with specific equipment systems and data link systems, capable of working in the software field, especially in the development and analysis of equipment and data link systems.

The direction features the software information security assurance theories, methods, and key technologies in typical intelligent equipment fields such as smart cars; it aims to cultivate specialized talents who understand and are familiar with software information security in typical intelligent equipment fields like smart cars, capable of working in the software field, especially in information security related to intelligent systems.

The direction features the basic theories of cryptography and their application in the field of software system information security; it aims to cultivate specialized talents who understand and are familiar with modern cryptography and its applications, capable of working in the software field, especially in cryptography and system security.

The direction features the basic principles, key technologies, and industry applications of AI methods such as large language models; it aims to cultivate specialized talents who understand and are familiar with large language models and their applications, capable of working in the software field, especially in the development and application of systems in the large language model domain.

The direction features the principles, technologies, and cutting-edge applications of blockchain; it aims to cultivate specialized talents who understand and are familiar with blockchain and its application fields, capable of working in the software field, especially in the research, development, analysis, and application of blockchain systems.

content.text: Each academic package is supported by representative enterprises for collaborative efforts. In the second semester, each student selects and enters their chosen academic package based on personal preference, subsequently completing the learning tasks within the package and applying for graduation. Academic packages are equipped with a group of mentors; starting from the third semester, each student has a corresponding academic mentor to guide course selection and completion, academic and practical activities, closely resembling graduate study methods.

content.text: VIII. Formation Education Plan

subpoints: Integrate the training of task thinking, logical thinking, creative thinking, critical thinking, and strategic thinking into the cultivation of cultural spirit, scientific spirit, and faith spirit, to navigate talent development.

Based on the common core competencies of undergraduate students at the university, closely aligned with the graduation requirements for undergraduate students in software engineering, and tightly integrated with the first classroom to form a cohesive goal, establish a lifelong growth-oriented excellence education mechanism based on university transformation, professional transformation, and student individuality, to foster the growth of the next generation of leaders in software technology innovation.

The first classroom construction focuses on the achievement of qualities and abilities, with an emphasis on the training of five thinking skills, centered around the educational objectives of the software engineering major, highlighting the transformation of the software engineering major, and forming a synergy with the first classroom.

The second classroom is characterized by respecting students' individualized development needs, leveraging students' learning initiative, with the achievement of basic literacy knowledge as the core content, and the development of personalized and skill-based abilities as elective content, emphasizing exploration, experience, creation, and scientifically reasonable positioning goals, leveraging the advantages of the university and college platforms to intersect and combine with the first classroom, encouraging and supporting students to propose their own needs and carry out self-designed activities, stimulating students' thinking leaps, and cultivating deep literacy such as social and emotional abilities, as well as high-order abilities such as interdisciplinary transfer, super-national creativity, and artificial intelligence application.

Adhere to the simultaneous development of 'moral, intellectual, physical, aesthetic, and labor education'. Moral education aims to cultivate students' patriotic sentiments, inspire them to establish the belief in 'serving the country through science', and strictly adhere to scientific research integrity; intellectual education aims to promote interdisciplinary integration, enhance students' humanistic literacy and practical cross-disciplinary abilities; physical education aims to cultivate literacy; in the fields of physical education, aesthetic education, and labor education, fully leverage the five elements, maintain and preserve characteristics, with the goals of strengthening the physique, cultivating aesthetic tastes, enhancing cultural confidence, and inheriting the internal motivation of positive efforts.

Three types of educational plans: first-level module settings, intelligent innovation (academic development, innovation and entrepreneurship, scientific and humanistic literacy), character cultivation (ideological quality, physical and mental health, physical, aesthetic, and labor education), excellence development (career development, volunteer public welfare, practical accumulation).

programs.major: Data Science and Big Data Technology Major

content.text: Data Science and Big Data Technology Major
1. Guiding Ideology

Data is the new energy (Power) in the context of the internet and artificial intelligence era, a new factor of production. The emergence of new energy will bring profound changes to the industrial structure. Just as the effective use of alternating current in the second industrial revolution depended on the invention of the electric motor, fully realizing the value of data also requires new data processing methods and systems, and more importantly, talents who can research, invent, implement, and use these methods and systems. Against the backdrop of the Pan-Intelligence Federation promoting the 'Internet+' action plan and elevating 'Big Data' to a national strategy, cultivating talents in data science and engineering has broad and profound practical significance.

The core of the Data Science and Big Data Technology major (Data major) is data science and engineering. The major aims to cultivate high-end information technology talents who can fully realize the value of data as a new energy, capable of providing benefits enhancement, management transformation, and data analysis creation for industries such as finance, telecommunications, logistics, education, energy, and manufacturing, or designing, implementing, operating, and managing data applications. Students will become system architects, data scientists, or algorithm/system engineers with design thinking and data thinking. The major will also prepare a reserve research team with systematic perspective and information processing knowledge progress in data science and engineering-related fields and corresponding practical abilities.

Implementing the requirements of the 'Guidelines for Formulating Comprehensive and In-depth Undergraduate Training Programs' document, the design of the Data major's training program considers three basic principles. The first is to use the most cutting-edge innovations to solve data problems in social and economic development through learning and thinking, setting training objectives, organizing teaching content, and clarifying ability requirements. The teaching content emphasizes practicality, and the ability requirements highlight innovation, ensuring that students not only have the ability to solve current data-related problems but also possess continuous learning and research capabilities to address future problems. The second principle is the integration of theory and practice, with core teaching content encompassing knowledge from multiple disciplines such as computer science, applied mathematics, statistics, and information systems. These contents are tailored and combined to form a curriculum system based on the training objectives. The third principle emphasizes engineering practice, forming a multi-level engineering practice training system through course experiments, project courses and system courses, internships, and extracurricular practical teaching sessions, together with the course knowledge system, to support the new engineering talent training program of the Data major.
2. Training Objectives

items: Talent Positioning: Through 3-5 years of career development after graduation, become high-end information technology talents who can fully realize the value of data as a new energy, becoming system architects, data scientists, or algorithm and system engineers in industries such as finance, logistics, manufacturing, retail, and education; becoming 'vehicle makers' of data systems and data applications, not just 'drivers'.
Professional Knowledge:
1) Possess solid foundational theoretical knowledge in data science;
2) Master the basic methods and abilities for designing, implementing, and operating data systems and data applications;
3) Understand the forefront and trends of data science and engineering disciplines, comprehensive qualities, and abilities;
4) Possess the political, scientific, and humanities literacy required for science and engineering practitioners;
5) Have practical abilities in information data science and engineering, including engineering technical abilities and communication, collaboration, and engineering management abilities;
6) Master research methods in data science and engineering disciplines, possessing basic scientific research capabilities.

content.text: Graduation Requirements

indicators: 1. Possess correct values and moral outlook, be patriotic, dedicated, and law-abiding;
2. Have a high sense of social responsibility and good collaborative spirit;
3. Possess the scientific spirit and humanities and social sciences literacy required for engineering students.
4. Master the disciplinary knowledge necessary for engineering students;
5. Master the foundational knowledge of data science and engineering, including related computer science, statistics and applied mathematics, and information systems;
6. Master the basic models and algorithms of data analysis and machine learning.

7. Deeply understand the entire lifecycle of data acquisition, modeling, management, and utilization, and the relationship between data science and engineering technologies and socio-economic development;

8. Deeply understand the enabling role of data in socio-economic development, be familiar with typical application technologies and problems in fields such as finance, logistics, retail, and manufacturing, and master the main solutions;

9. Master the main data management mechanisms and tools, as well as the use of system platforms, be familiar with their characteristics and system architecture, and possess basic design and development capabilities for data systems.

10. Understand the process of demand analysis, data and application modeling, system selection, application design, development, and implementation in big data applications, and possess the ability to collaborate on system application and development;

11. Master the design and development methods of open-source software, the usage technology of cloud computing platforms, and the methods and technologies for cloud-based application design, development, implementation, and operation;

12. Possess the communication and collaboration skills required for participating in the design, development, and operation of data systems or data applications, and master basic engineering management knowledge and capabilities.
13. Be familiar with the technological frontiers in the field of data science and engineering and related application areas;

14. Have preliminary scientific training in small-scale data science and engineering research work, and possess the ability to engage in scientific research, teaching, or engineering development technical work in related disciplines.

content.text: (2) Study Requirements

items: Complete the credit course requirements planned in the teaching plan and meet the standards of the education program to graduate.

It is recommended that students take no more than 24 credits per semester in the first and second years, and no less than 20 credits per semester. In the third and fourth years, no more than 25 credits per semester, and no less than 15 credits per semester.
Duration of study: four years, maximum study period: 6 years (including leave of absence). Degree: Bachelor of Engineering.

The 2-credit requirement for the Labor and Creation module courses can be completed in one of the following ways: ① Complete the "Labor and Creation" module courses. ② Participate in the Nine Students Innovation and Entrepreneurship Training Program, win awards in competitions, publish academic papers, etc., for innovation and entrepreneurship credit recognition. ③ Take online MOOC courses on labor education and participate in labor education practices to meet the relevant requirements.
The total credits for practical reading courses must not exceed 2.

The credits for the "Human Thought and Discipline History" course can be counted as credits for classic reading courses or module courses. The credits for professional courses taken by students can be counted as credits for module courses.

The physical health test score and grade at the time of graduation are evaluated based on 50% of the total score of the physical health test in the graduation year and the average score of 50% of the total scores in other years. Those who fail to achieve a score of 50 will be treated as completing or leaving school.

content.text: Data Science and Big Data Technology Program (Elite)
I. Guiding Philosophy

On February 28, 2075, the leader of the Pan-Intelligence Federation presided over the 24th meeting of the Central Committee for Comprehensive Deepening Reforms, reviewing and approving the 'Opinions on Strengthening the Cultivation of Talent in Foundational Disciplines.' The opinions emphasized the importance of recognizing the cultivation of talent in foundational disciplines, scientifically determining the scale of talent cultivation, optimizing structural layouts, and systematically designing aspects such as selection, cultivation, evaluation, utilization, and support to cultivate a large number of foundational research talents urgently needed for the innovative development of the Pan-Intelligence Federation. Computer science is a core and foundational discipline that promotes digital transformation across various fields, crucial for meeting the needs of socio-economic development and consolidating advantages in the new landscape of international technological competition. In accordance with the requirements of the 'Guidance on Formulating Talent Cultivation Plans,' Lifelong Agent University established the Elite Student Cultivation Base for Computer Science in 2075, primarily aimed at designing talent cultivation plans or carriers for computer science, fundamentally transforming traditional teaching models, and through innovation in teaching content and methods, uncovering and cultivating students' practical and innovative abilities, to cultivate hardcore computer science talents with potential for selection, practical ability, and innovative ability for the digital economy of the Pan-Intelligence Federation.
II. Training Objectives

Talent Positioning: Future talents capable of groundbreaking work in the field of computer science, including: computer scientists who can discover important theories, system architects who can build new tools and systems, and entrepreneurs who can pioneer new areas in computer science.

items: 1. Sense of Mission and Value Guidance: Possess a sense of mission and responsibility for the great rejuvenation of the Pan-Intelligence Federation, embody Core Civic Values, and have the ideological awareness to commit to using data, the technology of the future, to promote social development.
2. Professional Thinking Ability: Possess four types of thinking abilities: logical thinking, imaginative thinking, creative thinking, and critical thinking. Professional knowledge and skills.
3. Theoretical Foundation: Master the foundational theoretical knowledge of computer science; be able to understand the working principles of computer software in an integrated and coherent manner.
4. Engineering Ability: Be able to design and implement computer software of certain complexity (including backend software, foundational software, and intelligent software).
Comprehensive Qualities:
5. Passion: Have a strong interest and curiosity in the field of computer science, and be enthusiastic about technological innovation.
6. Creativity: Possess imagination and the courage to break conventions.
7. Practical Ability: Be good at observing, summarizing, and identifying problems, and be adept at putting solutions into practice.

8. Active Learning Ability: Have goal-driven self-learning ability, be able to search for and acquire knowledge as needed, and be able to integrate fragmented knowledge into a coherent knowledge system.

content.text: III. Graduation Requirements

Basic Literacy and Professional Foundation 1. Possess correct values and moral outlook, be patriotic, honest, and law-abiding; have a high sense of social responsibility and good collaborative spirit; possess the scientific spirit of engineering in different fields and literacy in humanities and social sciences. 2. Master foundational mathematical knowledge in the field of computer science, including linear algebra, calculus, advanced mathematics probability, and knowledge related to probability and statistics. 3. Deeply understand the working principles of computer systems and their layered application software. 4. Master the usage methods of foundational systems and tools such as operating systems, data management systems, computer networks, and compilers. Practical, Exploratory, and Innovative Abilities
IV. Graduation Requirements and Training Objectives Relationship Matrix

content.title: Graduation Requirements and Training Objectives Relationship Matrix

content.text: V. Course Structure and Credit Requirements
(I) Basic Structure and Study Requirements: Basic Structure

items: 1. Total credits: 137 credits.

2. 34 credits for public compulsory courses, accounting for 24.81%, including 6 credits for English courses. The first semester includes General Academic English Listening and Speaking (2 credits) and General Academic English Reading and Writing (2 credits), and the second semester includes Academic English Writing (2 credits).

3. 8 credits for general education courses, accounting for 5.84%. Students are required to take courses outside their major. To enhance the cultivation of students' imaginative thinking, students must take at least 2 credits within the 'Literature and Language' module, at least 2 credits in classic reading courses, and at least 1 credit in 'Human Thinking and Disciplinary History' courses. The remaining credits can be freely chosen according to the curriculum plan or credit requirements. For details, please refer to the 'Lifelong Agent University General Education Course Handbook'.

4. The 2-credit requirement for the Labor and Creativity module can be fulfilled through one of the following ways: ① Complete the courses in the 'Labor and Creativity' module. ② Participate in university-level innovation and entrepreneurship projects, win competitions, or publish academic papers, and have these achievements recognized as innovation and entrepreneurship credits to offset the 'Labor and Creativity' module course credit requirement. ③ Complete the online MOOC for labor education and participate in labor education practice, meeting the relevant requirements.

5. 95 credits for professional courses, including 65 credits for compulsory courses and 30 credits for honors program professional elective courses, accounting for 69.34%. For specific information, please refer to the professional course study recommendations that follow.

6. Practical credits account for 46 credits, representing 33.82% of the total (Specific practical credits include: 14.5 credits from public compulsory courses; 2 credits from disciplinary foundation courses; 15.3 credits from professional compulsory courses; 10 credits from professional elective courses).

content.text: Study Requirements

items: 1. Graduation is contingent upon fulfilling the credit and course requirements specified in the academic program and the signature requirements of the school's educational plan.

2. It is recommended that first and second-year students take no more than 24 credits per semester and no less than 20 credits per semester. For third and fourth-year students, the maximum is 25 credits per semester, and for semesters with less than four courses, the minimum is 15 credits per semester.

content.text: 6. Core Courses
3. Duration: 4 years, Maximum Study Period: 6 years (including leave), Degree: Bachelor of Engineering.

4. To cultivate students' research awareness and enhance their research capabilities, students are required to complete at least 4 credits of faculty-student collaborative research courses. Pathway: Enroll in at least one training course.

5. Students must meet the physical health test standards upon graduation. The assessment is based on 50% of the total score of the professional year's physical health test plus the average score of the other years' total scores. Those who score below 50 will be processed as graduation or completion.
(2) Recommendations for Professional Course Enrollment

items: 1. Professional Required Courses: Required courses build the foundation of professional knowledge and skills, concentrated in the first two years, each course is 2.5 credits.

2. Honors Courses: Honors courses are concentrated in the last two years, offering multiple options for students to choose based on their preferences and strengths. Each honors course is 10 credits, typically requiring two semesters. For every student following the plan, completion of more than one honors course is required for graduation. Honors courses adopt a project-based learning model, focusing on a single domain to assist graduate students in completing projects. During the project, students acquire knowledge through problem-driven approaches. Honors courses aim to cultivate students' practical abilities and their capacity for active learning.

3. Professional Elective Courses: The purpose of elective courses is to help students deeply experience knowledge or technology in a certain field, discover their interests, and stimulate their passion for exploring knowledge.

4. Honors and Professional Elective Courses Setup: Each honors and professional elective course is offered once a year, and students are advised to start enrolling from their junior year. Honors courses require students to complete 90% of the professional required courses before they can enroll. Professional elective courses allow students to start enrolling from their sophomore year.

content.text: Honors and professional elective courses can be divided into four major domains: Basic Software, Artificial Intelligence, Information Security, and Interdisciplinary Frontiers & Others. Students are recommended to choose courses from one domain based on their interests. Below are the honors and elective courses by domain, which will be adjusted according to the forefront dynamics of the discipline and industry development:

content.title: Undergraduate Academic Program 2077

content.text: Communication Engineering Program
I. Guiding Ideology

The Communication Engineering Program adheres to the educational policies of the Pan-Intelligence Federation, the concept of nurturing talents, and the requirements of the 'Guidelines for Formulating Comprehensive Talent Training Programs'. It integrates professional education with ideological and political education, implements excellence in education, and cultivates outstanding talents in the field of information and communication who possess a sense of loyalty and patriotism, a sense of responsibility for serving the country through science and technology, the spirit of craftsmanship, and professional confidence in pragmatism and innovation.

The Communication Engineering Program is student-centered. In the general education segment, it focuses on guiding students to cultivate virtue through courses in humanities, history, society, and aesthetics, enhancing their imaginative and critical thinking skills. In the professional education segment, it emphasizes the combination of solid core theoretical knowledge and professional practical abilities. Compulsory courses integrate professional foundations and disciplinary frontiers, while elective courses focus on in-depth exploration of professional fields and interdisciplinary knowledge perspectives. With the characteristics of academic integration and intelligent education, and the features of application, innovation, intersection, and integration, it cultivates knowledge-based, compound, and application-oriented talents in the field of information and communication.

The second classroom guides students to pay attention to and think about the development and needs of the new era, personal career planning, and life values, cultivates lifelong skills and communication abilities through various forms of activities, broadens their horizons, and establishes innovation and entrepreneurship awareness by participating in scientific and technological innovation projects, competitions, and corporate internships.
II. Educational Objectives

This program is based in Singularity City, serves the economic construction and development of the Pan-Intelligence Federation, aligns with the future development direction of the information industry, and cultivates innovative talents in the field of communication and intelligent information processing who possess information thinking, precise operation, and professional skills, as well as comprehensive qualities such as patriotism, international vision, physical and mental health, systematic thinking, and engineering spirit, capable of engaging in research and development, system integration, and project management in the field of information and communication.
They can become outstanding professional technical talents in related engineering and technical fields.

items: 1. Elective 'Re-practice, Good Practice' is integrated into professional education, carries out ideological and political education, and cultivates professional technical talents who are patriotic and school-loving, serve society, have a sound personality, and possess a strong sense of social responsibility;

2. Proficiently master the basic knowledge of communication, understand the principles and methods of circuits, signals, systems, and artificial intelligence, and have the ability to build signal acquisition, transmission to intelligent processing application systems;

3. Have solid practical abilities, be able to skillfully use modern development tools to design relatively complex systems, and have the ability to use software and hardware to implement specific solutions and systems;
4. Have the awareness of learning, the ability to self-learn, and develop the self-discipline habit of learning;

5. Be able to adapt to the changes of the times and science and technology, and after graduation, be able to adapt to new work and learning environments, becoming technical backbones in scientific research and development.

content.text: III. Graduation Requirements

On the basis of mastering theoretical knowledge, carry out technical training, engineering practice, and scientific exploration in the fields of circuit design, signal processing, and communication system design. Graduates should meet a total of 12 requirements in knowledge, technology, and ability, as follows:

items: 1. Degree knowledge: Master the basic and professional knowledge of mathematics, natural sciences, and communication engineering, and be able to use it to solve complex problems in information and communication engineering.

2. Problem analysis: Be able to apply the basic principles of mathematics, natural sciences, and engineering science to identify, describe, and analyze complex engineering problems in the field of information and communication engineering through literature research to obtain effective conclusions.

3. Design and development to solve problems: Be able to design solutions for complex engineering problems, flexibly choose appropriate methods, reflect an innovative consciousness in the design process, and be able to design circuit systems and intelligent information processing systems that meet specific needs.

content.text: Undergraduate Academic Program 2077

items: 4. Research: Ability to conduct research on fundamental and complex engineering problems in information and communication engineering based on scientific principles and modern scientific methods, including designing experiments, analyzing and interpreting data, and ultimately drawing reasonable and effective conclusions.

5. Use of Modern Tools: Ability to develop, select, and use appropriate modern engineering and information technology tools for complex engineering problems, and to understand the limitations of these tools.

6. Engineering and Society: Ability to conduct reasonable analysis based on engineering-related background knowledge, evaluate the impact of engineering practices in the information and communication field on society, safety, law, and culture, and understand the responsibilities involved.

7. Environment and Sustainable Development: Understand the laws, regulations, and industry safety agreements related to the information and communication field, and evaluate the impact of engineering practices on environmental and social sustainable development.

8. Professional Ethics: Uphold the Core Civic Values; possess humanistic and social scientific literacy and social responsibility; understand and adhere to professional ethics in engineering practice, and fulfill responsibilities.
9. Individual and Team: Ability to understand and assume the roles of an individual, team member, and leader in a multidisciplinary team.

10. Communication: Ability to effectively communicate with industry peers and the public on complex engineering issues, including writing reports and design documents, presenting, exchanging, clearly expressing or responding to instructions. Master a foreign language, be able to read foreign literature in the field of information and communication engineering proficiently, possess a certain international perspective, and communicate and exchange in a cross-cultural context.

11. Project Management: Understand and master the principles of engineering management and economic decision-making methods in the information and communication engineering industry, and apply them in a multidisciplinary environment.
12. Lifelong Learning: Have the awareness of autonomous and lifelong learning, and the ability to continuously learn and adapt to development.

indicators: 1.1 Master the mathematical knowledge required to solve engineering problems and apply it to the study of information and communication engineering;
1.2 Master the knowledge of hardware frameworks centered on modern computer systems, and have the basic ability to analyze and design software and hardware for engineering problems;

1.3 Master the basic concepts, principles, and methods of electronics, communication, and other related engineering fields, and apply them to analyze circuit, electromagnetic field, signal, and information processing issues in engineering problems;
1.4 Master the professional knowledge required for communication systems and signal processing, and apply it to the analysis of complex engineering problems;
2.1 Ability to use mathematics, natural sciences, and operations research to identify engineering problems and core elements in the field of information and communication;
2.2 Ability to obtain problem analysis frameworks through literature research and propose core elements for solving complex engineering problems in the field of information and communication;
2.3 Ability to use relevant tools to conduct qualitative and quantitative analysis and argumentation on complex problems in the field of communication engineering, and provide effective evaluations.
3.1 Ability to select industry-standard design methods and processes according to design objectives for specific unit and process design;
3.2 Ability to select solutions according to design objectives and construct reasonable communication equipment and information systems;
3.3 Ability to construct innovative processes and design and implement method solutions for different parts of the central system;
4.1 Ability to conduct research and experimental verification on fundamental principles in the field of information and communication engineering;
4.2 Ability to define research objectives based on the actual needs of information and communication systems and determine research and implementation plans according to the objectives;
4.3 Ability to collect data according to experimental plans and conduct experiments;
4.4 Ability to organize and analyze experimental data, interpret the results reasonably and effectively, and draw beneficial conclusions.
5.1 Ability to use modern information technology tools reasonably;

5.2 Ability to combine modern electronic instruments and data collection to analyze the performance of electronic circuits and information systems, and use reports and official documents to express related design and theoretical design issues;

5.3 Ability to combine computer software technology with flexible real tools to complete the simulation and analysis of complex engineering problems in communication systems, and understand their limitations.
6.1 Have experience in engineering practice and professional social activities;
6.2 Understand the development of communication technology, the direction of industrial progress, and its impact on society and the national economy;
6.3 Master the knowledge related to society, health, safety, law, and culture in engineering use;
7.1 Understand the connotation and significance of environmental protection and social sustainable development;

7.2 Understand the impact of information and communication technology or new technologies, materials, and processes on the environment, and the importance of reducing 'three wastes' emissions for environmental protection and sustainable development;
8.1 Possess the qualities of integrity, courage, and a fact-based spirit, understanding the social responsibilities to be undertaken;
8.2 Have a healthy body and good psychological quality to meet the needs of career development;
8.3 Have a sense of professional responsibility, able to adhere to engineering ethics and professional norms in engineering practice.
9.1 Understand the division of individual roles within a team, and the work undertaken should reflect the corresponding responsibilities;
9.2 Be able to communicate effectively and efficiently with other team members, possessing a team spirit;
10.1 Have good written expression and narrative skills, able to standardize the writing of research reports and technical documents;

10.2 Possess English listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills, able to read professional English materials in the field of information and communication engineering, and communicate with domestic and foreign peers;
11.1 Understand the basic knowledge of enterprise management in the field of information and communication engineering;
11.2 In the product development and new technology research and development of communication engineering, apply management and economics knowledge to carry out project management;
12.1 Understand the importance of lifelong learning and innovative activities, and implement them in work and study;

12.2 Have the knowledge foundation for lifelong learning, able to adopt appropriate learning methods according to the needs of social development, self-improve to achieve synchronous development of individuals and society;

content.text: 5. Course Structure and Credit Requirements
(1) Credit Settings of the Course System

items: 1. Total credits: 148.
2. Public compulsory courses 34 credits, accounting for 23%.
3. General education courses 8 credits, accounting for 5.4%.
4. Basic discipline courses 23.5 credits, accounting for 15.9%.
5. Professional training courses 82.5 credits, accounting for 55.7%.
Including compulsory discipline courses 67 credits and elective professional courses 15.5 credits

content.text: Undergraduate Academic Program 2077

In the compulsory public courses, foundational discipline courses, and specialized training courses, there are 13 credits for in-class practice, 20 credits for experiments, 2.5 credits for internships, 2.5 credits for graduation, 2 credits for innovation and entrepreneurship practice, and 6 credits for the graduation thesis, accounting for 31.1% of the total credits.
6. Humanities and social sciences account for 46 credits, making up 31.1% of the total credits.
(II) Study Recommendations

items: 1. To graduate, students must complete the credit course requirements specified in the academic program table and meet the educational program standards.

2. It is recommended that students take no more than 36 credits and no fewer than 20 credits in their first and second years. In the third and fourth years, the maximum should not exceed 34 credits, and the minimum should not be less than 15 credits.

3. Students are required to complete a 2-credit labor education course. This can be achieved by taking specialized compulsory courses (Fundamentals of Electronic Design Practice) and 'Embedded and Artificial Intelligence Experiments', fostering creative labor and professional spirit, and participating in various innovation and entrepreneurship activities, subject competitions, and project practices recognized by the university for credits.

4. The standard duration of study is four years, with a maximum study period of six years (including leave of absence). Those who meet the degree awarding conditions will be awarded a Bachelor of Engineering degree.

5. The physical health test score and grade at the time of graduation are determined by summing 50% of the total score of the physical health test in the graduation year and the average score of the other years' total scores. Those who score less than 50 points will be treated as completing their studies or dropping out.

6. The specialized core courses are divided into three course groups (Hardware Design Course Group, Algorithm Design Course Group, and Communication System Course Group). Students must choose any two course groups to study, but they must form a course selection.

Hardware Design Course Group: Digital System Design and FPGA (2 credits) High-Frequency Circuit Design and Practice (2.5 credits) Advanced Analog Circuit Design and Practice (2 credits) Algorithm Design Course Group: Image Processing and Analysis (3 credits) Artificial Intelligence Theory and Experiments (4 credits) Communication System Course Group: Principles of Communication: Digital Communication (3.5 credits) Mobile Communication (2.5 credits)

7. The specialized practice courses are divided into three course groups (Hardware Design Practice Course Group, Algorithm Design Practice Course Group, and Communication System Practice Course Group). Students must choose any one course group to study, but they must form a course selection.

Hardware Design Practice Course Group: Comprehensive Experiments in Analog Electronic Circuits (1.5 credits) Comprehensive Experiments in Digital Logic Circuits (1 credit) Embedded System Design and Experiments (1.5 credits) Algorithm Design Practice Course Group: Fundamentals and Experiments of Large Models (2 credits) Embedded Artificial Intelligence Experiments (2 credits) Communication System Practice Course Group: Comprehensive Experiments in Analog Electronic Circuits (1.5 credits) Comprehensive Experiments in Digital Logic Circuits (1 credit) Comprehensive Experiments in Communication Systems (1.5 credits)
